organization.$: School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Nanyang Technological Univerisity, Singapore, Singapore

head.citation-title: Evaluation of Single HMM as a Pre-Impact Fall Detector Based on Different Input Signals
head.abstracts: © 2018 IEEE.Accurate near-fall (pre-impact) detection has always been a goal of any fall prevention system. It allows for the early interception before an injury has been sustained by the user. This paper looks at the application of hidden Markov model (HMM) as a near-fall detector with different input signals from multiple IMUs. More input signals and post-processing may increase sensitivity but they also increase computation time and detection latency. This study aims to determine the simplest, fastest and most accurate HMM-based pre-impact fall detection algorithm. 5 IMUs placed at the torso, thighs and shanks are used for data collection. Multiple combinations of acceleration, gyroscope, orientation and quaternion are used as inputs to HMM, without any feature extraction or complex post-processing. Results show that the algorithm is capable of fall detection at about 200 ms after fall initiation with 90% sensitivity and 92% precision. The best performing IMU placements are at the torso and thigh. In addition, the computational latency of this algorithm can be as fast as 0.45 ms.

publisher.publishername: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

coredata.dc:description: Accurate near-fall (pre-impact) detection has always been a goal of any fall prevention system. It allows for the early interception before an injury has been sustained by the user. This paper looks at the application of hidden Markov model (HMM) as a near-fall detector with different input signals from multiple IMUs. Results show that the algorithm is capable of fall detection at about 200 ms after fall initiation with 90% sensitivity and 92% precision. The best performing IMU placements are at the torso and thigh. In addition, the computational latency of this algorithm can be as fast as 0.45 ms.
coredata.dc:title: Evaluation of Single HMM as a Pre-Impact Fall Detector Based on Different Input Signals
